head_templates.name: de-verb
head_templates.expansion: pflegen (weak, third-person singular present pflegt, past tense pflegte, past participle gepflegt, auxiliary haben)

head_templates.name: de-verb
head_templates.expansion: pflegen (class 4 strong, third-person singular present pflegt, past tense pflog, past participle gepflogen, past subjunctive pflöge, auxiliary haben)

etymology_text: From Middle High German phlëgen, from Old High German plëgan, from Proto-West Germanic *plehan.

derived.english: based on the past participle gepflogen

examples.text: jemanden gesund pflegen
examples.english: to nurse someone back to health

examples.text: Kranke pflegen
examples.english: to care for the sick

raw_glosses: Providing care or service for someone/something. [weak verb]
(transitive, medicine) to nurse; to care for someone in poor health
glosses: Providing care or service for someone/something. [weak verb]
to nurse; to care for someone in poor health

categories.name: German verbs using haben as auxiliary

examples.text: sein Äußeres pflegen
examples.english: to take care of one's appearance

examples.text: die Zähne pflegen
examples.english: to take care of (one's) teeth

examples.text: Der Gärtner pflegt den Garten.
examples.english: The gardener tends to the garden.

examples.text: Sie hat sich stets sehr gepflegt.
examples.english: She has always taken care of her appearance. (literally, “She has always taken care of herself.”)

examples.text: Er setzte sich faul hin und pflegte sich.
examples.english: He sat down lazily and went easy on himself. (literally, “He sat down lazily and looked after himself.”)

examples.text: Daten pflegen
examples.english: to maintain data (keep up-to-date)

raw_glosses: Providing care or service for someone/something. [weak verb]
(transitive) to take care of, to tend to, to maintain
glosses: Providing care or service for someone/something. [weak verb]
to take care of, to tend to, to maintain

categories.name: German verbs using haben as auxiliary

examples.text: Daheim labt er sich mit süssem köstlichem Wein, und pflegt seiner morschen Glieder in Kissen von Eider, während sein grosser herrlicher Sohn darbt.
examples.ref: 1781, Friedrich Schiller, Die Räuber: Ein Schauspiel, Frankfurt und Leipzig, page 43
examples.english: At home, he refreshes himself with sweet, delectable wine and cares for his decaying limbs with cushions of down feathers, all while his wonderful and charming son starves.

raw_glosses: Providing care or service for someone/something. [weak verb]
(transitive) to take care of, to tend to, to maintain
(intransitive, archaic, with genitive)
glosses: Providing care or service for someone/something. [weak verb]
to take care of, to tend to, to maintain

raw_glosses: To improve or care for something in an intellectual sense. [weak or strong verb]
glosses: To improve or care for something in an intellectual sense. [weak or strong verb]
To improve or care for something in an intellectual sense.

categories.name: German verbs using haben as auxiliary

examples.text: Freundschaften pflegen
examples.english: to cultivate friendships

examples.text: Beziehungen pflegen
examples.english: to cultivate relationships

examples.text: Künste und Wissenschaften pflegen
examples.english: to advance/promote the arts and sciences

raw_glosses: To improve or care for something in an intellectual sense. [weak or strong verb]
(transitive) to cultivate; to foster; to nurture; to maintain
glosses: To improve or care for something in an intellectual sense. [weak or strong verb]
to cultivate; to foster; to nurture; to maintain

categories.name: German verbs using haben as auxiliary

examples.text: der Liebe pflegen
examples.english: to cultivate/nurture love

examples.text: der Ruhe pflegen
examples.english: to foster tranquility

raw_glosses: To improve or care for something in an intellectual sense. [weak or strong verb]
(transitive) to cultivate; to foster; to nurture; to maintain
(intransitive, higher register or poetic, with genitive)

categories.name: German verbs using haben as auxiliary

examples.text: Umgang pflegen
examples.english: to regularly be in contact

examples.text: Geselligkeit pflegen
examples.english: to socialize regularly (literally, “to regularly engage in gregariousness”)

raw_glosses: Expressing habituality. [weak or strong verb]
(transitive) to carry out regularly

categories.name: German verbs using haben as auxiliary

examples.text: Ich pflege zu laufen.
examples.english: I usually walk.

examples.text: Er pflegte zu reisen.
examples.english: He used to travel.

raw_glosses: Expressing habituality. [weak or strong verb]
(intransitive, with “zu” followed by an infinitive verb) to perform habitually; to be accustomed (to doing something); to be in the habit (of doing something)
glosses: to perform habitually; to be accustomed (to doing something); to be in the habit (of doing something)
tags: with “zu” followed by an infinitive verb

categories.name: German verbs using haben as auxiliary

head_templates.name: de-noun
head_templates.expansion: Fuchs m (strong, genitive Fuchses, plural Füchse, diminutive Füchslein n or Füchschen n, feminine Füchsin)

etymology_text: From Middle High German vuhs, from Old High German fuhs, from Proto-West Germanic *fuhs, from Proto-Germanic *fuhsaz, from Proto-Indo-European *púḱsos (“the tailed one”), from *puḱ- (“tail”). Cognate with English fox, Sanskrit पुच्छ (púccha).

examples.text: Fuchs, du hast die Gans gestohlen. Gib sie wieder her!
examples.english: (line from a popular children’s song)
examples.roman: Fox, you stole the goose. Bring it back again!

examples.text: Er ist ein ganz schöner Fuchs.
examples.english: He is a really handsome fox.

raw_glosses: (informal) a clever or cunning person

examples.text: Unser Paul ist ja ein kleiner Fuchs.
examples.english: Our Paul is a little redhead.

raw_glosses: (informal) a red-haired person or horse.
(military, slang) A new recruit.

examples.text: Ich hatte nur vier Trümpfe und darunter beide Füchse.
examples.english: I had only four trumps and among them were both aces of diamonds.

raw_glosses: (card games) In Doppelkopf, the ace of diamonds, which earns a side of players an extra point if they win it from the other side
glosses: In Doppelkopf, the ace of diamonds, which earns a side of players an extra point if they win it from the other side

raw_glosses: (military) a tank Transportpanzer Fuchs
(archaic) A form of sunscald on hops.
glosses: A form of sunscald on hops.

raw_glosses: (obsolete) any gold coin

head_templates.name: de-noun
head_templates.expansion: Herz n (weak, genitive Herzens or (very rare) Herzes, plural Herzen, diminutive Herzchen n or Herzlein n or ((also) Ruhrpöttisch) Herzken n)

args.1: n,ens:es􂀿very rare􂁀.weak.dat:en:-􂀿as a card suit or term of endearment, otherwise informal􂁀

etymology_text:
From Middle High German herze, from Old High German herza, from Proto-West Germanic *hertā, from Proto-Germanic *hertô (“heart”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱḗr (“heart”).
Cognate with Dutch hart, English heart, Danish hjerte, Gothic 𐌷𐌰𐌹𐍂𐍄𐍉 (hairtō).

raw_glosses: (card games) hearts

categories.name: German entries with incorrect language header

head_templates.name: de-noun
head_templates.expansion: Fahrer m (strong, genitive Fahrers, plural Fahrer, feminine Fahrerin)

categories.name: German entries with incorrect language header

etymology_text: From Middle High German von (“from”), from Old High German fon, fona (“from”), from Proto-Germanic *afanē, *fanē, *funē (“from”), compound of *afa (from Proto-Indo-European *h₂epó (“from, off”)) + *ana (from Proto-Indo-European *h₂en- (“on”)). Cognate with Old Saxon fana, fan (“from”), Dutch van (“from; of”), Old Frisian fon (“from”).

examples.text: Ich fahre von Köln nach Hamburg.
examples.english: I'm travelling from Cologne to Hamburg.

examples.text: Ich hab’s von meiner Schwester gehört.
examples.english: I heard it from my sister.

examples.text: das Auto meines Vaters = das Auto von meinem Vater
examples.english: my father’s car / the car of my father

glosses: of, belonging to (often replacing genitive; see usage note below)

categories.name: German usage examples with omitted translation
German entries with incorrect language header

examples.text: Das Hotel wird von der Firma bezahlt.
examples.english: The hotel is paid for by the company.

examples.text: Er hat von seiner Jugend erzählt.
examples.english: He told about his youth.

examples.text: Von dem Nomine Substantivo, oder dem Hauptworte.
examples.ref: 1796, Abraham Sahlstedt, Schwedische Grammatik nach dem Sprachgebrauch unserer Zeiten, Lübeck & Leipzig, page 259
examples.english: About the substantive noun, or the [alternative term]. (headline)

examples.text: Von welchem Geld soll ich als Arbeitsloser in Urlaub fahren?
examples.english: Being unemployed, on what money should I go on holidays?

examples.text: Man kann nicht nur von Luft und Liebe leben.
examples.english: You can’t live on air and love alone. (proverb)

etymology_text: From Middle High German base, from Old High German basa, from Proto-Germanic *baswǭ (“father's sister; paternal aunt”). Compare Saterland Frisian Bääsje (“grandmother”), Dutch baas (“master; boss”). More at boss.

raw_glosses: (archaic) A female cousin.
(obsolete) paternal aunt

etymology_text: 19th c., backformation from Basen, plural of Basis, from Latin basis, from Ancient Greek βάσις (básis).

raw_glosses: (chemistry) base (compound that will neutralize an acid)
glosses: base (compound that will neutralize an acid)

categories.name: German entries with incorrect language header
